Tired of getting your PRs rejected by CI because of a long line? These days are over!

The new longLine linter will highlight long lines, so your PRs will always be green!

:smile:

#15097

This line is 101 characters long.

The current linter apparently allows lines of that length.

I imagine that the limit should be 100 and 101 should be rejected, right?
I'm currently reviewing this PR, and this was going to be the only substantial question I wanted to ask :-)
In principle, I agree with you. In practice, 33 lines are too long at the moment - are you volunteering to reformat them? If so, I don't object :-)
This obviates the "line length linter" from Linters/Textbased: would you like to remove it in this PR or shall I do so in a follow-up?
Once CI finishes, I will take a look at the lines that it flagged and will decide if I increase 100 to 101, or I shorten the exceptions! :grinning:

Besides the 101-characters long lines, the bulk of the linter warnings were in the tests for doc-strings of #guard_msgs.

  • Should the linter ignore such long lines by default?
  • Should users replace spaces by line breaks (which #guard_msgs regards as equivalent)?
  • Should users explicit silence the linter with set_option linter.longLine false in?
At the moment, I silenced the linter using a combination of adding set_options and replacing spaces by line breaks. I could instead special case #guard_messages, if that is preferred.
I think test stuff (so eg #guard_msgs) should just be ignored

I am not so sure about unlinting tests. I am in favour of being more liberal with uses of set_options in test files, but I still think that tests should try to comply with the standards of the whole project.
In this particular case, I view the 100 character limit as addressing a legibility concern and I am not sure that tests should be exempted from that.
Oh no I can't believe that the "101 characters is actually OK" secret is now public!

Damiano Testa said:

In this particular case, I view the 100 character limit as addressing a legibility concern and I am not sure that tests should be exempted from that.

Yes but I don't think #guard_msgs are supposed to be legible? Also they are supposed to be easily autogenerated

In practice, no #guard_msgs line will be longer than 100 chars + epsilon, so I don't really see the value in forcing people to manually wrap their autogenerated #guard_msgs lines for non-existent readers
Ah, ok! I interpreted your message as "the test folder should not be linted"! I'll look into unlinting just #guard_msgs.
Well, I also mostly think that "the test folder should not be linted" but I agree this is more controversial!

Unlinting #guard_msgs is a bit tricky and I could only find a solution that I do not like too much. Unless I come up with a better solution (or someone else provides one :smile: ), I would prefer to leave the unlinting of #guard_msgs to either adding line breaks to the text or using set_option.

EDIT: writing what is in the comment history, I figured out my mistake: I was trying to silence the linter on the command guarded by #guard_msgs. What I should do, is to silence the #guard_msgs doc-string and that appears to be completely straightforward.

I made the change. The only lines that are longer than 100 characters that the linter allows are

  • the ones that contain the substring http;
  • the doc-strings of #guard_msgs,and the actual #guard_msgs in characters;
  • anything where the linter option is set to false.

I am pretty happy with all of the above, to be honest!
Do we want to run this linter on non-Mathlib projects by default? It might be distracting for new users. Or does it teach them a useful convention early?

Hopefully, the "per-project option setting" will be available soon and these issues will be less relevant.

I do not have a strong opinion on this specific linter. In general, I wonder whether all linters should be off by default and then each project sets whatever option they want to be on or not.

(What I do not like too much, is putting guards on the linters that inspect the path of the file and if they see that it does not start with Mathlib then they do nothing: this effectively makes projects that want the linter to not have access to it.)
The long line linter is triggering also on downstream projects. It should be mathlib-only.

#15226

As I mentioned above, I am not too happy with this kind of solution, but I also do not know of a better one -- until "new" options can be set per project!
this is on its way in the next release, I think

I don't know if you noticed, but this linter triggers on scripts/mk_all.lean when running it:

warning: ./././scripts/mk_all.lean:67:0: This line exceeds the 100 character limit, please shorten it!
note: this linter can be disabled with `set_option linter.longLine false`
Is that file supposed to be linted?

Personally, I had not thought about the fact that this file would be linted, but I also do not see a real problem with that! If this is something that we want to take seriously, we should make sure that CI checks that no file is noisy, though.
branch#MR-line-length-scripts has a fix. I have not checked if this the only violation
